Award.AwardTitle: Sitka Whalefest Scientist in Residency Fellowship
Award.AbstractNarration:
In collaboration with the Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence (COSEE) Alaska, Sitka Whalefest, will bring four nationally renowned marine scientists to Sitka, Alaska each year for one-month fellowships.

The proposed Scientists in Residency Fellowship (SIRF) will create outreach and educational programs for the students of Mt. Edgecumbe High School, a state-run boarding school whose student body is 90 percent Native Alaskan, and for the K-12 students of Sitka School District, which is 33 percent Alaska Native as well as for the local community. It builds on an already successful program, Scientists in the Schools, developed by Sitka Whalefest, which coordinates visiting scientists? presentations and hands-on activities with the school curriculum and extensive advance preparation with science teachers in K-12 classrooms.

As proposed, each SIRF will provide individual scientists a month-long period in a unique setting to think creatively and to work on broader scientific ideas, such as completing data analysis, writing up research results, thinking about new research questions, and about how their work can be integrated into other scientific work. It will also provide occasions for exchanges between practitioners of Western science and Indigenous knowledge.

The Fellows will give school and community presentations to improve ocean literacy for coastal subarctic and arctic residents, communicate their research to the public, attempt to interest students in scientific careers, update science teachers on new scientific theories and techniques and cultivate cross-cultural exchange of observations of the marine ecosystem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Scientist in Residency Fellowship awarded Fellowships to 17 mid-career marine scientists in a variety of disciplines and career paths for one month residencies in Sitka, Alaska, a rural coastal community, heavily dependent on the sea.  These scientists each spent a week of their Fellowship in the classroom, community, and public venues to present their science and also to benefit from discussions with, and the experience of, coastal residents, Alaska Natives, commercial fishermen, subsistence users, and local students.  The goals were to increase ocean literacy, energize students in the study and potential careers in science, and showcase Sitka as a valuable research center to faciliate important and locally relevant marine research.  Science was shared through classroom presentations and field trips with 19 different classes (inlcuding the entire 8th grade) in the Sitka School District (30% Alaska Native) and Mt Edgecumbe High School (90% Alaska Native), summer camps, Science cafes, public radio interviews, Rotary and library talks, Natural History Seminar Series presentations, and, importantly, through daily contact with residents as the Fellows lived their lives in Sitka for a month. This unique immersion into the community "humanizes" scientists to students and coastal residents, making them, and their science, accessible while also providing rare opportunities for scientists to undertand the perspecitive of coastal residents through extended conversation and fellowship. The Fellows were aided in Science Communication training and were provided student and teacher evaluations of their classroom interactions as a direct feedback for future presentations. Teachers, students, and fellows evaluated the Fellowship very positively. An independent evaluation of the 3 year program attributed the increase in Alaska Science Standard Scores above the statewide average in 2015 in large part to the SIRF fellowship program.
